case_vignette: A 68-year-old man comes to the phys   ician 3 months after noticing skin changes on his scalp. When he scrapes off the crust of the lesion, it reappears after a f   ew days.    Occasionally, his scalp itches or he  notices a burning    sensation. He had a mole removed on his  right forearm 5 years ago. He is a retired winemaker. His vital signs are within normal l   imits. Examination shows multiple rough patche s on his scalp. A photograph is shown.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've noticed some skin changes on my scalp, and when I scrape off the crust of the lesion, it reappears after a few days. Sometimes my scalp itches or I feel a burning sensation.
Have you noticed similar changes on other parts of your body or only on your scalp?
The changes are only on my scalp.
Have you had any hair loss in the areas where you've noticed the skin changes?
No, I haven't experienced any hair loss in those areas.
Do you have a personal or family history of skin problems such as eczema, psoriasis, or other skin conditions?
No, I don't have a history of skin problems like eczema or psoriasis.
Do the lesions bleed or ooze any fluid when they are scratched or disturbed?
No, the lesions do not bleed or ooze any fluid when they are scratched or disturbed.
Are the lesions scaly and/or does the scale appear white, silvery, or yellowish in color?
The lesions are scaly and rough.
Final Diagnosis: Seborrheic Dermatitis
